description: Change of use from take away (A5) to Nail salon (Sui Generis) including internal refurbishment, small rear single storey extension and new shopfront.
decision_conditions: The development hereby permitted shall begin before the expiration of three years from the date of this permission.Reason: As required by section 91 of the Town and Country Planning Act 1990, as amended by section 51 of the Planning and Compulsory Purchase Act 2004.

The development shall be carried out in accordance with the material specified on the approved plans and application form unless otherwise agreed by the Local Planning Authority. Reason: To ensure a satisfactory appearance on completion of the development in accordance with policy DM10 Design Requirements for New Developments (including house extensions) of the LDF Core Strategy Adopted April 2012.

No building or use hereby permitted shall be occupied or the use commenced until the cycle parking provision shown on the approved plans has been completed, and thereafter, be kept free of obstruction and available for the parking of cycles only.Reason: To ensure the provision of adequate cycling facilities in accordance with Policy DM10 (Design Requirements for New Developments including House Extensions) of the LDF Core Strategy Adopted April 2012.

5.	No development shall take place including any works of demolition until a construction logistics plan has been submitted to and been approved in writing by the Local Planning Authority.  The approved plan/statement shall be adhered to throughout the construction period. The statement shall provide for:(a) Provision for loading/unloading materials.(b) Storage of plant, materials and operatives vehicles.(c) Temporary site access.(d) Signing system for works traffic.(e) Measures for the laying of dust, suppression of noise and abatement of other nuisance arising from development works.(f) Location of all ancillary site buildings.(g) Measures to protect any tree, shrubbery and other landscape features to be retained on the site during the course of development.(h) Means of enclosure of the site.(i) Wheel washing equipment.(j) The parking of vehicles of the site operatives and visitors(k) The erection and maintenance of security hoarding.(l) A scheme for recycling/disposing of waste resulting from demolition and  construction works (Major Applications).Reason: In order to safeguard the amenities of the surrounding residential occupiers and to safeguard highway safety and the free flow of traffic in accordance with Policy DM10 (Design Requirements for New Developments including House Extensions) of the LDF Core Strategy Adopted April 2012.These details are required prior to commencement of development because:- to safeguard residential amenity and to ensure the works are planned in a way which would not cause significant disruption at a town centre site where the free flow of traffic could be impeded particularly at peak times.

No customers shall remain on the premises outside the hours of 09:00am to 19:00pm Monday to Saturday, and on Sundays/Bank Holidays outside the hours 10:00am to 16:00pm.Reason: To safeguard the amenities of the occupiers of the neighbouring properties in accordance with Policy DM10 (Design Requirements for New Developments including House Extensions) of the LDF Core Strategy Adopted April 2012.

I acknowledge receipt of your payment for £ 1250.00, unfortunately the fee required for this application is £ 1775.00 (for meeting and advice note), therefore please forward the outstanding balance of £525.00 as soon as possible.Note: If payment is by cheque please make payable to Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames or if by card please call our Contact Centre on direct line 0208 547 5002. You may also pay online via the RBK website www.kingston.gov.uk

It is necessary to serve Certificate B on the freeholder of the property as well as on all owners with a 7 year interest (leasehold) in the land.  The notification needs to be addressed to each individual flat owner (not just management company) and a list of all those notified (by name and/or address) submitted as part of Certificate B.  Please use the previous application form you used to complete again and enter the information required
Please be advised that a Full Planning Application form is required for works to a self-contained flat, which should include the correct ownership certificates being signed.

Based on provided description of proposed works, the fee required for your planning application is £ 96.00.  Payment can be made via either our Contact Centre on 0208 547 5002 or by cheque made payable to Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames

The proposed plans supplied, do not correspond with the proposals.  Your proposal describes works to be done to 13 single or group of trees according to my count namely: (Small Beech, Small Thuja, Multi Stem Lime, Cherry x2, Yew, Small Shrub, Horse chestnut cluster, Elda and lilac cluster, Horse Chestnut, Cuppresses, Purple Royal x2, Box Shrubs and Holly) however, your 'Tree sketch plan' only outlines 6 Trees namely, (Lime, Cherry Trees x2, Horse Chestnut Cluster, Cuppresses, Box Shrubs and Holly).  Please therefore, update the Tree plan by naming and numbering each tree eg; T.1 Beech. -Fell and grind stump completely. etc;  exactly as I have done above if you agree with my naming/numbering, or, send a new Tree Plan Sketch with updated information using the example provided, regarding all the trees cited in the amended proposal.  Further, you have made mention of the following: 'Elda and lilac in cluster are poor specimens and the Horse Chestnut will lift the drive and possibly interfere with the foundations of the garage and adjacent drainage. Pittosporum will be replanted here'. Please confirm if you are proposing any works for the 'Elda & Lilac trees' mentioned above and if so, what works you would like to be carried out.  Please supply this information at your earliest convenience.Confirmation can be in writing or by amending the plans to reflect the proposals.
The assessment has been based on the original layout of the house. Officers note alterations to the original outrigger.

Your attention is drawn to the fact that planning permission does not override property rights and any ancient rights of light that may exist.  This permission does not empower you to enter onto land not in your ownership without the specific consent of the owner.  If you require further information or advice, you should consult a solicitor.

The Party Wall Act 1996 requires a building owner to notify, and obtain formal agreement from any adjoining owner, where the building owner proposes to carry out work to an existing party wall, build on the boundary with a neighbouring property or, in some circumstances, carry out groundworks within 6 metres of an adjoining building.Notification and agreements under this Act are the responsibility of the building owner and are quite separate from Building Regulations, or Planning Controls.  The Building Control Service will assume that an applicant has obtained any necessary agreements with the adjoining owner, and nothing said or implied by the Council should be taken as removing the necessity for the building owner to comply fully with the Party Wall Act. Further information and advice is to be found in "The Party Walls etc. Act 1996 - Explanatory Booklet".

The developer should be advised that the highway authority will require them to enter into an Agreement under Section 278 of the Highways Act 1980 in respect of all the necessary highway works including footway and carriageway resurfacing on Hampden Road in the vicinity of the development area.
The applicant can contact the Highway Authority on 020 8547 5002.

Inspection:Site inspection carried out as a desktop exercise with information provided by the applicant as supporting material to application.Assessment:The only works applied for requiring permission are those to the Whitebeam on the frontage. The works are minimal in nature and are repeat works regularly undertaken with no ill effect upon the tree or the amenity contribution it offers.Recommendation:Approve.

Inspection:Site inspection carried out as a desktop exercise with information provided by the applicant as supporting material to application.Assessment:Minor works to reduce slight overhang from neighbouring property. Trees are to the rear and the works will have no impact upon public amenity.Recommendation:No objections.

Inspection:Site inspection carried out as a desktop exercise with information provided by the applicant as supporting material to application.Assessment:Acceptable minor works without negative impact on tree health or on amenity.Recommendation:Approve.

Inspection:Site inspection carried out as a desktop exercise with information provided by the applicant as supporting material to application.Assessment:The works to remove pollard regrowth are both necessary and appropriate both to reduce impact upon the building and also for health and safety reasons, but the additional removal of the 3rd trunk is not acceptable and would have too great an impact on both the trees health and its amenity value. This is not acceptable in light of the TPO.Recommendation:Refuse & grant lesser works as follows:T.9 Ash - Repollard to previous points only.

Inspection:Site inspection carried out as a desktop exercise with information provided by the applicant as supporting material to application.Assessment:The applicant has submitted adequate justification for the removal of T.3 Oak, but the application includes the removal of T.4 Yew the roots of which tree have not been found in bore hole samples and as such the evidence submitted is insufficient to justify the removal of this second tree.Recommendation:Refuse & grant lesser works as follows:T.3 Oak - Fell.
